I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the additional financing of the Green Power Development Project.1  
 
2.  The additional financing will cover a cost overrun for construction of the Dagachhu 
hydropower plant component of the project, which was approved in 2008. The higher-than-
estimated  costs  have  mainly  resulted  from  unexpected  geological  conditions  found  during 
excavation works for underground facilities. The overrun will not change the scope of the project 
and is relatively small in relation to the original cost estimate. The financial and economic 
viability of the component remains viable despite the overrun. There are no outstanding or new 
safeguards issues.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The Green Power Development Project has two components: the Dagachhu hydropower 
plant, and a rural electrification program. Now nearing completion, the run-of-river generation 
plant will have an installed capacity of 126 megawatts (MW), and its output will be exported to 
India through an existing cross-border grid network.2 The electrification investment has been 
completed and provides electricity to 8,886 households and public institutions in remote rural 
areas by extending an existing grid and through the use of off-grid solar home systems.3  
 
4.  The Dagachhu hydropower development is the first public–private partnership in the 
Bhutan’s infrastructure sector. The private partner is the Tata Power Company, one of India’s 
premier companies. Its subsidiary, the Tata Power Trading Company, will be the offtaker for the 
plant’s electricity. The government’s investment has been channeled through its national utility, 
the Druk Green Power Corporation (DGPC). The new assets have been placed under a special 
purpose company—the Dagachhu Hydro Power Corporation (DHPC). The government and its 
public agencies own 74% of DHPC’s shares.4 The project’s rural electrification component was 
executed by another national utility, the Bhutan Power Corporation (BPC), and the Ministry of 
Economic Affairs.5 
 
5.  The remaining Dagachhu plant construction work will be physically completed by the 
original loan closing date of 31 December 2013. About 95% of the work is done.6 More than 
98%  of  the  overall  finance  extended  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been 
disbursed, except for a small amount set aside for interest during construction.  
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loans, Asian 
Development Fund Grant, Technical Assistance Grant, and Administration of Grant to the Kingdom of Bhutan for 
the Green Power Development Project. Manila. 
2  The Dagachhu hydropower plant is in southwestern Bhutan and 20 kilometers (km) from the border with India. 
3  The rural electrification component has achieved the target within the planned cost and timeframe. 
4  The project’s shares are held by DGPC (59%), the National Pension and Provident Fund of Bhutan (15%), and the 
Tata Power Company (26%).   
5  BPC is mainly responsible for transmission and distribution while DGPC looks after generation. The off-grid rural 
electrification was carried out by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.  
6  The main works outstanding are (i) 0.3 km of tunnel excavation (out of 11 km in total), and (ii) overall aligning. The 
remaining rock conditions in the tunnel are good. The electromechanical equipment has been installed in an 
underground powerhouse. The transmission line is ready to evacuate power.

2 
6.  The original project cost was $234.5 million. ADB provided and administered $106.3 
million under the financing plan (Table 1). The hydropower plant cost was estimated at $201.5 
million, $80.0 million of which was to be provided by ADB in (i) a $29.0 million loan from the 
hard-term facility of the Asian Development Fund, and (ii) a $51.0 million loan from ordinary 
capital  resources.  The  project  received  cofinancing  from  an  Austrian  commercial  bank—
operating under the Austrian export credit agency (OeKB)—and Bhutan’s National Pension and 
Provident Fund (NPPF). The balance has been mobilized as equities from the government and 
project sponsors including DGPC, NPPF, and the Tata Power Company.

7.  On 26 February 2010, the Dagachhu hydropower component was registered as the 
world’s first cross-border Clean Development Mechanism project. DHPC later signed a certified 
emissions reduction purchase agreement with ADB, which acts as a trustee of the Future 
Carbon Fund, to sell carbon credits generated from the Dagachhu plant.   
 
8.  The project was classified as safeguard category B for environment and resettlement 
and category C for indigenous peoples. No households were relocated for the plant component 
but 25 were compensated for partial loss of land for the construction of access roads. All 
environmental safeguards have been complied with in full. The cost overrun raises no new 
safeguard issues.  
 
9.  The plant’s planned capacity was optimized from 114 MW to 126 MW.7 The bid prices 
for the equipment were 20% higher than the estimates, but this extra cost was financed by 
proportionate additional equity investments by the project sponsors.8 All civil work costs fell 
within the original estimate. However, the underground tunneling excavations required extra 
reinforcement due to unexpected poor geological conditions, which raised the cost of the works 
over time.9 The civil work costs were also increased by large escalations in the labor and

material prices.10 The two factors combined raised the overall cost estimates for the Dagachhu 
plant by 16.6%.11 In spite of these cost increases, the project remains technically sound and 
financially  and  economically  viable.  The  sponsors  are  fully  satisfied  with  the  technical 
performance of the contractors.12   
 
10.  Construction of the Dagachhu plant is near completion. The overall project has been 
performing well and is rated satisfactory on the ADB project performance rating system. It meets 
the standard performance criteria of (i) expected output delivery; (ii) satisfactory implementation 
progress;  (iii)  satisfactory  compliance  with  safeguard  requirements;  (iv)  successful  risk 
management for implementation; and (v) an on-track rating in terms of technical performance, 
contract awards, disbursements, financial management, and safeguard compliance.13 
 
11.  The government is requesting additional financing from ADB to complete the project. 
The government sees the Dagachhu hydropower development as a high national priority. The 
project  has  been  implemented  along  with  its  Sustainable  Hydropower  Policy,  2008,  which 
introduced private sector investment in hydropower development in Bhutan for the first time. 
ADB is also helping the government prepare a second public–private partnership project to 
generate hydropower for export as a follow-up to the Dagachhu project.14 The government thus 
aims to accelerate power exports through both public and private investments. Based on an 
umbrella agreement between Bhutan and India, an additional 10,000 MW of hydropower is to be 
developed and exported by Bhutan by 2020.15 Bhutan now exports 70% of the electricity it 
generates to India, and the power sector is the largest source of both government revenue and 
gross domestic product.16 Hydropower is the backbone of Bhutan’s economy.   
 
B.  Impact and Outcome  
 
12.  The impact will be sustained inclusive economic growth through cross-border power 
trade and domestic electricity access. The outcome will be expanded coverage of sustainable 
clean power supply.17 
 
C.  Outputs  
 
13.  The outputs of the Green Power Development Project will be (i) constructed hydropower 
plant; (ii) extended rural electrification; and (iii) improved DGPC management systems. The 
Dagachhu hydropower plant is expected to be commissioned in 2014 after construction work is 
completed within 2013. The intended rural electrification output has already been achieved 
(para.  3).  DGPC  management  systems  have  been  improved  as  a  result  of  capacity 
development technical assistance attached to the project.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The project’s scope is unchanged, and the implementation arrangements will remain the 
same. The executing agency is DGPC, and the implementing agency is DHPC. As the special 
purpose project company, DHPC is fully staffed and functional.  
 
18.  The additional financing will be used for extra costs of the existing Dagachhu civil works 
procured under ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. Retroactive financing will be allowed for an 
amount not exceeding 20% of the additional financing loan amount for the civil work costs 
incurred prior to loan effectiveness of the additional financing and within 12 months of the 
signing of the additional loan agreement.   
 
19.  The Dagachhu hydropower plant is expected to be in full operation in April 2014 after 
testing and commissioning.

the project administration manual.21

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
22.  The generators have been installed in the plant’s underground powerhouse, and 19 km 
of 220 kV transmission lines from the plant are completed and ready to evacuate power. The 
major remaining work is tunnel excavation, although it involves only 0.3 km of the 11 km total 
works.23 The assessment of an ADB project site technical inspection was that this would be 
completed before the loan closing date of 31 December 2013. DHPC intends to operate the 
plant at full generation capacity in the second quarter of 2014, when the next rainy season starts. 
Since Dagachhu will be the country’s fifth major hydropower plant, the staff of DGPC and DHPC 
are  experienced  in  plant  operations.  The  project  construction  designs  and  operations  are 
technically sound.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
23.  The PPA base tariff was increased from Rs2.4 per kilowatt-hour to Rs2.9 per kilowatt-
hour on a cost-plus basis (para. 21). The conservative financial internal rate of return adjusted 
for higher tariffs and costs is 2.61%, higher than the weighted average cost of capital.24 The 
economic  adjusted  internal  rate  of  return  is  16.04%,  and  the  Bhutan–India  subregional

7

hurdle  rates  by  margins  sufficient  to  substantiate  the  project’s  financial  and  economic 
sustainability with the additional financing. 
 
24.  Climate change modeling analysis has suggested hydrological increases in the project 
area for the future, which would enable the plant to increase annual generation output (para. 
32). The revised PPA includes profit-sharing mechanisms to sell electricity in the India’s power 
trading market at higher rates. These scenarios will increase the power sales, and improve the 
Dagachhu plant’s financial and economic performance. Even under several negative business 
scenarios considered, DHPC will maintain the covenanted debt service coverage ratio of 1.2. 
The additional financing will increase DHPC’s financial leverage where the debt–equity ratio will 
rise from 60:40 to 66:34.  
 
C.  Governance 
25.  The ADB capacity development technical assistance provided under the original project 
was successfully implemented and achieved institutional improvements. As a result, DGPC and 
DHPC adopted comprehensive corporate policies and manuals on accounting and financial 
management, inventory and procurement management, internal audit, human resources, and 
safeguards. In 2011, these improvements were supported by management information systems 
provided through an enterprise resources system package. The external independent auditor 
reported that these entities have adequate internal control systems, suitable budgetary systems, 
adequate competitive bidding, and sufficient organizational system control to carry out their 
operations in an orderly and efficient manner. 
 
26.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, DGPC, and DHPC. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
27.  The  project  site  is  in  Dagana  District,  a  remote  area.  During  implementation,  the 
Dagachhu development has greatly improved the local community’s access to many services 
and opportunities. The following improvements have had a positive poverty and social impact in 
local communities:    
(i)  Transportation. To carry heavy machines and materials, the conditions of roads 
and bridges in the area were drastically improved. These benefits were realized 
early  on  in  project  construction.  Better  connectivity  and  improved  physical 
accessibility  are  greatly  needed  in  Bhutan’s  remote  communities  due  to  the 
difficulties of travel in the country’s mountainous terrain.  
(ii)  Social  services.  DHPC  adopted  its  corporate  social  responsibilities.  It 
constructed and renovated school classrooms and provided school buses for 
safe student transport. It made clinic services available to local people for free.26 
(iii)  Electrification. Rural electrification was carried out in project area communities 
along with Dagachhu plant’s construction. BPC extended its distribution lines, 
which accelerated rural electrification in the project-affected areas and the district 
overall. This was the main tangible benefit from power generation development

return was estimated at 13.80% under the original loans. The subregional economic internal rate of return was 
22.00% as well.  
26 More than 1,600 local people had received the medical services as of February 2013.

8 
for local people. Most of households in the  project areas had no access to 
electricity previously or only limited access on off-grid solar lighting.27   
(iv)  Commercial  activities.  A  local  economic  boon  of  the  project  has  included 
employment opportunities, rental income, increased small business activity, and 
sales of farm products to project staff and workers. 28  
 
28.  The  original  project  aimed  to  sustain  the  country’s  inclusive  economic  growth  by 
promoting cross-border power trade and access to domestic electricity access.29 Royalties from 
the  project’s  power  export  revenue  will  help  sustain  affordable  electricity  prices  for  rural 
households  through  a  clear  regulatory  framework.  The  power  exports  will  also  generate 
additional government resources to promote socioeconomic development in rural areas.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
29.  The cost overrun and additional financing will change neither the project’s scope nor its 
original safeguards categorizations for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous 
peoples. DHPC’s environmental unit has provided ADB with periodic monitoring and updated 
reports on the implementation of safeguards.30 There are no outstanding safeguard issues.31 
 
30.  Social safeguards. The project is classified as category B for involuntary resettlement 
and  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  In  June  2008,  DHPC  prepared  a  resettlement  plan.  The 
resettlement  activities  were  carried  out  under  this  plan  at  the  initial  stage  of  project 
implementation  in  2008–2009,  before  the  construction  contract  award.  All  25  affected 
households who lost part of their land due to construction of plant access roads opted for land 
replacement.32 Of these households, 20 also received cash compensation for crop losses on 
their  land  at fair market  value.33 There  are  no outstanding  involuntary  resettlement  issues 
associated with the additional financing.   
 
31.  Environmental safeguards. The project’s environmental category is B. Based on an 
initial environmental examination, an environmental management plan has appropriately been 
carried  out.34 During  implementation,  DHPC  conducted  separate  studies  that  included  (i) 
additional fish migration monitoring; (ii) water, soil, and air quality measurements; and (iii) 
appropriate  minimum  ecological  flow  assessment  based  on  more  data  on  seasonal  water 
                                                
27 Almost 1,000 households in the project-affected areas were connected to the grid under BPC’s own program after 
the Dagachhu project started.    
28 The Dagachhu project created about 1,500 job opportunities, including employment for about 300 local workers, 
drivers, and helpers hired by DHPC and its contractors.   
29 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
While the original project had positive gender impacts through the rural electrification component, the project as a 
whole needed no gender elements or specific gender measures beyond the core labor standard requirements.    
30 DHPC assigned five full-time staff to the unit. ADB provided capacity development technical assistance to train 
them and develop the safeguard manuals.  
31 Social Safeguard Compliance Assessment and Environmental Safeguard Compliance Assessment (accessible 
from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
32 The  affected  households  were  asked  to  choose  land  of  an  equivalent  size  and  similar  productivity  from 
government-owned land to replace what the land they lost. In 2009, all had received ownership certificates for the 
replacement lands. 
33 Cash compensation was done in two stages in May and September 2008. Because recent market data for crop 
and tree prices were lacking, the compensation rates were revalued by the government’s property assessment 
valuation authority. The resultant rates were 3–4 times higher than the previous rates. Bhutan has since based its 
approach to crop compensation in other projects on this practice.   
34 A team of environmental experts and other experts from ADB, DGPC, and DHPC visited all project construction 
sites in May 2013. Site rehabilitation, slope stabilization, and tree planting were in evidence at all the sites. Other 
environmental management was satisfactory and reflected the requirements of the environment management plan.

9 
quantity variation. Bhutan’s National Environment Commission was also involved in the process. 
While there were no endangered or long-distance migratory fish in the Dagachhu River, DHPC 
adopted construction of a fish ladder to help maintain the native ecosystem. The commission 
has verified periodic assessments of water, soil, and air quality. The minimum ecological water 
was found sufficient to aquatic habitat conditions. While DHPC continues monitoring activities, 
there are no existing or developing issues related to environmental safeguards. 
 
32.  Climate change impacts. Hydropower resources are vulnerable to negative climate 
change  impacts.  Climate  change  modeling  analyses  were  undertaken  using  eight  climate 
models  from  various  organizations.  They  projected  long-term  water  flow  increases  in  the 
Dagachhu  watershed  that  should  benefit  the  plant.35 The  analysis  showed  the  Dagachhu 
hydropower plant to be hydrologically sound and its adaptation design to be effective. The plant 
faces low technical, financial, social, and environmental risks from climate change. It will have a 
positive  climate  change  impact  under  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism,  eliminating  the 
500,000 tons of potential carbon dioxide emissions that would otherwise be produced each year 
in India by fossil fuels to generate the electricity it will provide for export from Bhutan.  
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
33.  Since  the  Dagachhu  hydropower  plant  is  near  completion  and  adequate  mitigation 
measures have been built into the original design and implementation arrangements, the overall 
project risks are considered low. Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 
5 and described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.36  
 
Table 5: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Construction  The  major  work  outstanding  involves  only  a  short  distance  of  the  overall  tunnel 
risk  excavation works. The work has been progressing steadily, and geological conditions 
have been assessed as manageable. Experienced international geologist, engineers, 
and contractors are on site.     
Operational  The plant’s run-of-river hydropower operations are straightforward. DGPC staff with 
risk  experience operating existing hydropower plants have been assigned to DHPC. The 
(management)  private  development  partner  (Tata  Power  Company)  has  sufficient  experience  in 
implementing and operating other hydropower projects.    
Offtake risk  A long-term PPA was signed with one of the leading power trading companies in India. 
The offtaker’s credit risk is further mitigated in the PPA by an adequate payment 
security mechanism.   
Climate  Climate change modeling analysis assesses the Dagachhu watershed as hydrologically 
change risk  sound. Sufficient adaptation measures were adopted in the structures, facilities, and 
adjoining areas of the project to address such potential disasters as floods, landslides, 
and earthquakes.       
Currency risk  DHPC adopted a foreign exchange fluctuation reserve fund to mitigate the repayment 
risk of foreign currency loans.  
DGPC = Druk Green Power Corporation, DHPC = Dagachhu Hydro Power Corporation, PPA = power purchase 
agreement. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
                                                
35 Climate Change Risk Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). Under the climate 
change modeling analysis, the annual water flow in the Dagachhu watershed is projected to increase by 1%–4% 
during the non-monsoon months (November–March) and by 10%–15% during the monsoon months (June–
October) toward 2041–2060. 
36 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
34.  The government, DGPC, and DHPC have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, and disbursement as described in detail in the 
project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
35.  The government, DGPC, and DHPC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan and project agreements. A condition for the effectiveness 
of the additional financing will be that the subsidiary loan by the government to DHPC is 
acceptable to ADB in form and substance.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR25,689,000 to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the additional financing of 
the Green Power Development Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest 
charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; 
for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
